On Wed, 14 Oct 1998 Dedpetvet@aol.com wrote:

> One of the problems with making oatmeal stouts is the high level of gums in
> the oatmeal.  These gummy stuff will stick up your mash and give you several
> heaaches and loooooong lauder times.  There are two ways around this.  One is
> to include a large handful of rice hulls in the mash or add extra grain and
> grind it faurly coursely.  The other is to include a beta-gluconase rest at
> 120 degrees F. for 30 minutes This will break these gums into shaller pieces.

When I do a beta glucan rest (which is whenever I use oats, or lots 
of wheat, for the reasons Bill mentions) I do it at 104 degrees F
for 30 minutes.  This has always worked well for me.  I've been 
told that some microbreweries do a rest at 104 degress for as much
as three hours.  I use 104 for the first rest based on the
recommendations of George Fix, author of several brewing textbooks, who
vociferously advocates a 40-60-70 Celsius schedule (104-140-158 F, 
30 mins at each).  He claims that this will yeild maximum extraction
for most recipes, and a good balance between a- and b-amylase activity.

And now that you mention it, does anyone know where to get rice hulls
around here?  Mike at American Brewmaster ordered some for me but he
had trouble getting the order filled and they never arrived.  As
an alternative, last time Cait and I brewed a Bavarian Weiss with
50% wheat malt, we went to Southern States (the farm supply store)
and got a big sack of "table bran" which is basically wheat husks,
and used some of that as a filter aid in the grain bed.  We got 
great runoff, but somehwat reduced extraction efficiency.  I'll be
bringing this beer to Trub tonight if anybody is interested in talking
about the technique.

Kevin.
